Please allow me to give a slightly different opinion. This might be unconventional, but has worked tremendously for me. I will also preface this by saying that I've never found career fairs, large info sessions, or any event where there are large numbers of other students to be helpful. 

So, what should you do? Reach out to UC Berkeley graduates who work at the company you are interested in. That's it. Now, you might ask, what should I do from here?

First of all, you should be reaching out to companies you are truly interested in and people who are in positions you can also see yourself in. This will allow you to come from a place of genuine curiosity and passion. Second of all, you should be ready to meet these people for quick coffee chats or engage with them over the phone. Finally, you should have questions and talking points prepared beforehand. These conversations can be nerve-wracking and if you've prepared you will maximize your chance of success.

So, what should I actually say? Try to focus the conversation on them! Ask about their experiences that have led them to this point, ask questions about their work that implicitly show your knowledge, perhaps push the envelope and ask about things that aren't normally disclosed, ask about their opinions on industry trends, etc. The point is, you want to show interest in them and their company. If you are coming from a genuine place, the conversation will flow naturally. 

How does this help me with recruiting? If you feel that the conversation went well, you might feel comfortable mentioning the fact that you are interested in applying for an internship/full-time job at their company. If they also thought the conversation went well, and you've impressed them, they will either recommend you directly to the recruiter or just plain secure you a first-round interview. Put yourself in their shoes. They (presumably) care about their company and want to hire other passionate, honest, and hard-working people. You've proved these qualities by going to UC Berkeley (just like they did!) and having this wonderful conversation with them. You are now much more than just a piece of paper (resume) and have put yourself ahead of many others! 

Good luck and let me know if you have any questions!
